articles.headline: Report Finds Naval Blockade by Israel Legal but Faults Raid
articles.snippet: A United Nations review found that Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza was appropriate, but the way commandos boarded a flotilla trying to break the blockade was excessive.
articles.abstract: A United Nations review found that Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza was appropriate, but the way commandos boarded a flotilla trying to break the blockade was excessive.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A long-awaited United Nations review of Israel’s 2010 raid on a Turkish-based flotilla in which nine passengers were killed has found that Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza is both legal and appropriate. But it said that the way Israeli forces boarded the vessels trying to break that blockade 15 months ago was excessive and unreasonable.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: In Japan, a Tenuous Vow to Cut
articles.snippet: Yoshihiko Noda, new Japan’s prime minister, is a fiscal conservative with a tough message: raise taxes while reining in spending.
articles.abstract: Yoshihiko Noda, new Japan’s prime minister, is a fiscal conservative with a tough message: raise taxes while reining in spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As Japan’s fiscally conservative finance minister, Yoshihiko Noda long sounded the alarm on the nation’s ballooning government debt. It is more than twice the size of its $5 trillion economy — and rated more risky than that of Italy and Spain.

articles.headline: Banks Push Greek Bailout Plan
articles.snippet: Banks are doing their part to push through a second bailout for Greece, but the deal is shaping up to be better for them than for the Greeks.
articles.abstract: Banks are doing their part to push through a second bailout for Greece, but the deal is shaping up to be better for them than for the Greeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — No bank likes to take a loss, especially those in Europe that already suffer from a toxic mix of thin capital, troubled financing and weak loan books.

articles.headline: Tech Blogger to Invest in Start-Ups
articles.snippet: Michael Arrington, who writes about start-ups for the TechCrunch blog, is opening a fund to invest in the same kinds of companies.
articles.abstract: Michael Arrington, who writes about start-ups for the TechCrunch blog, is opening a fund to invest in the same kinds of companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Michael Arrington, whose influential TechCrunch blog covers Silicon Valley, has started a venture capital fund to invest in start-ups, including some that he and his staff write about.

articles.headline: A Little Give in the Dress Code
articles.snippet: Schools are incorporating more stylish clothes into their dress codes, and retailers have been happily catering to the changes.
articles.abstract: Schools are incorporating more stylish clothes into their dress codes, and retailers have been happily catering to the changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: As more and more schools adopt dress codes, back-to-school shopping is often a rather dull exercise. Polo shirts. Khaki pants. Plaid skirts. As the students might say, bo-ring.

articles.headline: T-Mobile May Suffer if AT&T Deal Fails
articles.snippet: Should the Justice Department’s lawsuit kill the proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile USA, some analysts say it could harm T-Mobile, its competitiveness sapped by months of limbo.
articles.abstract: Should the Justice Department’s lawsuit kill the proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile USA, some analysts say it could harm T-Mobile, its competitiveness sapped by months of limbo.
articles.lead_paragraph: When AT&T agreed to buy T-Mobile USA in March, the deal looked like a happy fate for a company that had been losing customers and facing declining sales.

articles.headline: In Libya, Former Enemy Is Recast in Role of Ally
articles.snippet: Abdel Hakim Belhaj, in charge of the military committee responsible for keeping order in Tripoli, says he was tortured by C.I.A. agents in his former life as emir of the Libyan Islamic Fighting Group.
articles.abstract: Abdel Hakim Belhaj, in charge of the military committee responsible for keeping order in Tripoli, says he was tortured by C.I.A. agents in his former life as emir of the Libyan Islamic Fighting Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Abdel Hakim Belhaj had a wry smile about the oddity of his situation.

articles.headline: Plan to Create Jobs Is a Balancing Act for the President
articles.snippet: The challenge for President Obama is to highlight his sharp differences with Republicans — and to be pragmatic enough to get their votes.
articles.abstract: The challenge for President Obama is to highlight his sharp differences with Republicans — and to be pragmatic enough to get their votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anticipation of President Obama’s plan for creating jobs while cutting deficits, now heightened by the scheduling controversy over his prime time address to Congress next Thursday, has turned on a question: Will he go big and highlight his sharp differences with Republicans, or will he be pragmatic and downsize his ideas to get Republican votes?

articles.headline: U.S. Is Set to Sue a Dozen Big Banks Over Mortgages
articles.snippet: The federal agency that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is expected to sue Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and others, accusing them of failures in vetting mortgages during the housing bubble.
articles.abstract: The federal agency that oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is expected to sue Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and others, accusing them of failures in vetting mortgages during the housing bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal agency that oversees the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is set to file suits against more than a dozen big banks, accusing them of misrepresenting the quality of mortgage securities they assembled and sold at the height of the housing bubble, and seeking billions of dollars in compensation.

articles.headline: Scanning 2.4 Billion Eyes, India Tries to Connect Poor to Growth
articles.snippet: Using the same powerful technology that transformed the country’s private economy, the government is creating a vast identity database that it hopes will help relieve chronic inequality.
articles.abstract: Using the same powerful technology that transformed the country’s private economy, the government is creating a vast identity database that it hopes will help relieve chronic inequality.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALDARI, India — Ankaji Bhai Gangar, a 49-year-old subsistence farmer, stood in line in this remote village until, for the first time in his life, he squinted into the soft glow of a computer screen.

articles.headline: Zero Job Growth Latest Bleak Sign for U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: The unemployment rate stayed constant at 9.1 percent in August, the first time in 11 months that there has been no job growth in the United States.
articles.abstract: The unemployment rate stayed constant at 9.1 percent in August, the first time in 11 months that there has been no job growth in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: August brought no increase in the number of jobs in the United States, a signal that the economy has stalled and that inaction by policy makers carries substantial risk.

articles.headline: Lots of Vitriol for Fed Chief, Despite Facts
articles.snippet: Ben Bernanke has become a favorite target of criticism, but many of the missives about him are without substance.
articles.abstract: Ben Bernanke has become a favorite target of criticism, but many of the missives about him are without substance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Attacks on the chairman of the Federal Reserve aren’t new. For years I’ve received a well-organized volley of vitriolic e-mails every time I mention Ben Bernanke. I dismissed them as missives from the lunatic fringe, at least until recently.
